Entries.Thu4: Peter is such a wonderful person, and he's so good with kids.$h#$b# Have you ever noticed how patient and encouraging he is with Yuuma and Jas? He really is quite amazing.$h
Entries.Sun4: What is that word? Focal? Factual? Fall-Oh!#$b#Sorry, @, I forgot the technical term for something I was trying to explain to Peter and it's driving me crazy.$h
Entries.Wed6: I try to assist Peter when he's teaching the children, but I'm much better one-on-one than with a group, so I mostly end up reminding the kids to listen to him. #$b#He's really good at staying patient and going at their pace.$h
Entries.ArchaeologyHouse: {{Random: It's interesting to compare the children's learning styles. Keahi and Vincent are strongly kinesthetic learners, while Yuuma and Jas are auditory learners and Trinnie is predominantly visual. It must be difficult to create lesson plans that accommodate all of them.$6, *whispering to herself* Oh... As I do recall, Piaget's theory in cognitive learning focused on assimilation and accomodation of information... But his study environment could hardly be called controlled-- He used his own children as subjects...$6#$b#So can his data really be considered accurate...? Hmm...$6, In order for educational outcomes to be met, an educator must first observe Maslow's hierarchy and ensure that the pupils' base needs are met before learning can be properly facilitated. That is to say, if the children aren't getting adequate food and sleep, it's difficult for them to study.$6, It appears Peter has been utilising Kolb's cycle of learning with the children. Where possible, he creates opportunities for concrete experiences, asks the children to reflect on their observations and conceptualize their findings, then has them apply their learnings in other areas. It's a good approach.$6, It's interesting to compare the children's learning styles. Keahi and Vincent are strongly kinesthetic learners, while Yuuma and Jas are auditory learners and Trinnie and Eloise are predominantly visual. It must be difficult to create lesson plans that accommodate all of them.$6}}

Entries.Wed6: When I help out at the library, I sometimes get to see the classes Peter teaches to the children.#$b#He's real smart.$h#$b#I'd like to sit in some time, but I'm kind of embarrassed.$s

Entries.Thu6: Mister Peter is such a good teacher!#$b#I learned about different animals the other day!$h#$e#Miss Flor is also a lot of fun to talk to.$h#$b#But sometimes she uses words I don't know and it gives me a headache!$u

Entries.Tue4: Demetrius has been real welcoming to me.#$b#I'm afraid he might get the wrong idea. Maru's like a little sister to me.#$e#I'm actually rooting for Peter and Maru.$h
Demetrius has been real welcoming to me.#$b#I'm afraid he might get the wrong idea. Micah's like a little brother to me.#$e#I'm actually rooting for Peter and Micah.$h

Entries.funReturn_Flor: {{Random: Today's sessions went well.$h#$b#I never get sick of the walk home... It's a really good opportunity for me to just practice being mindful and present.$h, I think the kids learned a lot today. And Gunther received the book I requested from interlibrary loan, so it was a good day all around.$h, @, I'm home.#$b#That's such a joyful thing to be able to say.$4, I'm back, @. Peter and the children all send their regards.$h, I'm back, honey. You'll never guess what Trinnie said today.$h#$b#She is surprisingly perceptive for someone of her age.}}

Entries.TwoKids_2: I think I'm going to ask Peter for tips on teaching the kids all kinds of stuff.$h#$b#I want them to get the education I never had.#$b#I'll be the best teacher dad!$h
Entries.Good_1: I've been making some progress on my reading.#$b#Peter and Flor said they're impressed!$h

Entries.Thu6: Keahi has been learning a lot from Peter...$s#$b#%Pika sighs deeply.#$b#Don't get me wrong, I'm grateful for what he's doing for Keahi.$h#$b#I just sometimes think about what it would be like if his makuahine, his mother, was here.$4

Entries.Tue8: Maybe I could join Mister Peter and Miss Flor and teach the children.#$b#Maybe one day.$h

Entries.Wed8: I'm on my way to the beach to practice my cartwheels! Wanna come with me @? It's gonna be so much fun! I can do a perfect cartwheel, Mister Peter says so!

Entries.Tue2: Mister Peter is such a good teacher!$h#$b#I learn so much from her.#$e#I have only one day a week to spare for school though.$s
Entries.Wed6: I study a lot at home most of the time.#$b#Mister Peter helps me while Mr. Philip is helping Shiro.
Entries.Resort_Chair: Maybe I should have brought a book with me.#$b#Mr. Peter says I should read more...

Entries.flor.read: {{Random: It's interesting to compare the children's learning styles. Keahi and Vincent are strongly kinesthetic learners, while Yuuma and Jas are auditory learners and Trinnie is predominantly visual. It must be difficult to create lesson plans that accommodate all of them.$6, *whispering to herself* Oh... As I do recall, Piaget's theory in cognitive learning focused on assimilation and accomodation of information... But his study environment could hardly be called controlled-- He used his own children as subjects...$6#$b#So can his data really be considered accurate...? Hmm...$6, In order for educational outcomes to be met, an educator must first observe Maslow's hierarchy and ensure that the pupils' base needs are met before learning can be properly facilitated. That is to say, if the children aren't getting adequate food and sleep, it's difficult for them to study.$6, It appears Peter has been utilising Kolb's cycle of learning with the children. Where possible, he creates opportunities for concrete experiences, asks the children to reflect on their observations and conceptualize their findings, then has them apply their learnings in other areas. It's a good approach.$6, It's interesting to compare the children's learning styles. Keahi and Vincent are strongly kinesthetic learners, while Yuuma and Jas are auditory learners and Trinnie and Eloise are predominantly visual. It must be difficult to create lesson plans that accommodate all of them.$6}}
